items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Following the Budget Study Session, the Board of Trustees reviewed a set of principles and adopted a set of assumptions designed to provide the policy framework for the Chancellor and Executive Staff in the development of a District Budget for the 2011-2012 fiscal year.  In particular, these include:
	 
PRINCIPLES
	 
The Board will provide a policy framework, and the Chancellor and staff will execute/implement specific reductions within that framework
Budget reductions must consider a "student centered" perspective to mitigate to the extent possible the impact on students
Budget reduction strategies must address the findings and concerns regarding fiscal solvency identified by the Accrediting Commission
Strategies must be immediate and long term and include multiple year solutions
	 
ASSUMPTIONS
The proposed District Budget assumes the state budget reductions that are the "best case scenario"
The implementation of six budget reductions strategies
Reduction in Force– Any reduction in force will be fair and equitable and will based on the percentage of full-time personnel at the District (19%), EVC (41%) and SJCC (40%).
Salary Reductions - These would be negotiated with respective labor representatives.
Benefit Restructuring - These would be negotiated with respective labor representatives.
Workload Reductions - These would be developed by the college presidents in consultation with their participatory governance groups identifying the most efficient ways to address FTES (full time equivalent student) reductions.
Cost Savings - All would be involved in identifying cost savings at each of the key operational organizational levels of the district.
Resource Development - The District Office and both colleges are involved in this effort with the Workforce Institute, SJECCD Foundation and the Research Office being specifically charged with focusing on resource development opportunities 
The adoption of a prudent reserve of 7%
The inclusion of budget reduction strategies that are permanent in nature and not just "one time" or "soft money"
Ongoing modification to budget goals to reflect changes in state apportionment figures and pending negotiations with District Labor Representatives

items.item_details:
According to many sources, including the State Chancellor’s Office, The Community College League of California, the Department of Finance and the Legislative Analyst Office, the 2011-2012 budget development process for community colleges statewide has many challenges:
	 
Worst budget year in the history of the state of California with a $25 billion shortfall.
Abbreviated legislative timeline for budget proposals of February 28, 2011, imposed on the State Legislature by the Governor’s Office. 
Changes in leadership in the Assembly and Senate
Uncertainty of ultimate budget reductions pending the outcome of the extension of tax revenues
Proposed changes in the community college apportionment based on student retention instead of the established census date report on student enrollment
Increase in student fees by $10/unit (from $26 to $36)
National focus on community colleges
	 
In addition, there are a number of local factors specific to the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) that must be addressed including:
	 
Accreditation findings, concerns and recommendations regarding fiscal solvency
Structural budget deficit that has not been addressed
The need to establish a “prudent” reserve to meet fiscal standards
	 
The SJECCD Board of Trustees has requested an extended budget study session to facilitate “informed” and “data based” decision making in advance of critical budget approval and contractual obligation timelines.  In particular, the Budget Study Session will focus on the following:
Fiscal Responsibilities for California Community College Trustees: Leadership Benchmarking for Trustees
Budget Overview
Current Budget Year ( 2010-2011)
2011-2012 Budget Year
Four Year Projections - 2010 to 2014
Reserve Policy
What constitutes a “prudent reserve”
Budget Reduction Strategies
A review and analysis of budget reduction strategies
Resource Development Strategies
Review of Budget Development Principles
Budget Development and Budget Approval Timelines
Next Steps
	 
It is expected that this session will be interactive with ongoing discussion, questions and answers throughout the session.
